docs.title: Сообщество сварщиков — Cloude AI
docs.text:
Добро пожаловать на сайт сообщества сварщиков‑энтузиастов! Здесь ученые и специалисты‑практики делятся опытом, теориями, методиками, параметрами режимов и реальными кейсами.

  • Исследуете физику процесса? Смотрите раздел «Теория».
  • Настраиваете оборудование и параметры? Загляните в «Практика».
  • Публикуете новые подходы и результаты? Делитесь в «Статьи и опыт».

Наша цель — объединить знания и сделать их применимыми в цехе, лаборатории и на производстве.

docs.title: С чего начать
docs.text:
• Ознакомьтесь с «Быстрым стартом» и «Теорией».
  • Проверьте «Практику»: оборудование, параметры, наладка.
  • Посмотрите «Трудности» — типовые проблемы и их решения.

docs.title: Присоединяйтесь к сообществу
docs.text:
• Как подготовить материал: см. «Шаблоны материалов».
  • Как оформить вклад: см. «Как внести вклад».
  • Уважайте «Кодекс поведения».

docs.title: Тематические направления
docs.text:
• Физика дуги и процессы переноса.
  • Микроструктура и металлургия сварных соединений.
  • Параметры режимов, стабилизация и контроль качества.
  • Автоматизация, сенсоры, компьютерное зрение, модели.
  • Практика: подготовка кромок, присадки, оборудование, безопасность.

Если у вас уже есть материал — смело публикуйте заявку через «Предложить статью» в Issues.

docs.title: Краткое описание
docs.text: Опишите цель изменений и их ценность.

docs.title: Тип изменений
docs.text:
• [ ] Новая статья / материал
  • [ ] Обновление существующего контента
  • [ ] Техническое улучшение (навигация, сборка)
  • [ ] Исправление ошибок

docs.title: Контент
docs.text: Если статья: - Аннотация: - Ключевые слова: - Основные разделы завершены? (да/нет) - Ссылки добавлены? (да/нет)

docs.title: Проверка
docs.text:
• [ ] Локально собран сайт (mkdocs serve)
  • [ ] Нет битых ссылок
  • [ ] Формулы отображаются корректно
  • [ ] Изображения имеют подписи

docs.title: Дополнительно
docs.text: Скриншоты, графики, замечания.

docs.title: Связанные Issues
docs.text: Ссылка на Issue (если есть).

docs.title: Кодекс поведения
docs.text: Мы стремимся к открытому, уважительному и инклюзивному сообществу. Этот кодекс поведения обязателен для всех участников: авторов, ревьюеров, мэйнтейнеров и читателей.

docs.title: Принципы
docs.text:
• Уважение: избегайте грубости, дискриминации, личных нападок.
  • Конструктивность: критикуйте идеи, а не людей; предлагайте улучшения.
  • Доброжелательность: помогайте новичкам, делитесь контекстом и источниками.
  • Научная добросовестность: указывайте источники, отделяйте факты от мнений.

docs.title: Неприемлемое поведение
docs.text:
• Оскорбления, харассмент, дискриминация по любым признакам
  • Публикация чужих данных без согласия, нарушение конфиденциальности
  • Намеренное распространение неверной или вводящей в заблуждение информации

docs.title: Последствия
docs.text: Нарушения могут повлечь предупреждение, редактирование/удаление контента, временную или постоянную блокировку участия.

docs.title: Репортинг
docs.text:
Сообщить о проблеме можно через Issues/PR или напрямую мэйнтейнерам. По возможности приложите контекст (ссылки, скриншоты, цитаты).

Следуя этому кодексу, мы создаем безопасную и продуктивную среду для обмена знаниями.

docs.title: Как внести вклад
docs.text: Спасибо за интерес к проекту! Мы приветствуем вклад как от ученых, так и от специалистов‑практиков.

docs.title: Формы вклада
docs.text:
• Статья/отчет об исследовании (раздел «Статьи и опыт»)
  • Практическое руководство, чек‑лист, параметры режимов
  • Поправки и дополнения к существующим страницам

docs.title: Быстрый процесс
docs.text:
1. Форкните репозиторий и создайте ветку из main.
  2. Для статьи используйте шаблон из «Шаблоны материалов».
  3. Локально соберите сайт, убедитесь, что все ссылки и формулы отображаются.
  4. Откройте Pull Request: опишите суть, дайте краткую аннотацию и ключевые слова.

docs.title: Локальная сборка
docs.text:
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -r requirements.txt
mkdocs serve
Сайт откроется на http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: Стиль и оформление
docs.text:
• Ясная структура: введение → методика → результаты → обсуждение → выводы
  • Иллюстрации: подписи, единицы измерения, читаемость в темной/светлой теме
  • Формулы: используйте KaTeX ($...$ и $$...$$)
  • Ссылки на источники: по возможности с DOI или ссылками на открытый доступ

docs.title: Review
docs.text:
Каждый PR проходит техническую проверку (сборка/навигация) и содержательную (корректность, воспроизводимость). Просим отвечать на вопросы ревьюверов и при необходимости вносить правки.

См. также: «Кодекс поведения».

docs.title: Шаблоны материалов и правила публикации
docs.text: Чтобы упростить ревью и сделать материалы сопоставимыми, используйте следующий шаблон.

docs.title: Шаблон статьи (исследование/методика)
docs.text:
• Название
  • Краткая аннотация (2–4 предложения)
  • Ключевые слова
  • Введение (контекст, постановка задачи)
  • Методика (оборудование, материалы, параметры, дизайн эксперимента)
  • Результаты (графики/таблицы/фото, основные наблюдения)
  • Обсуждение (интерпретация, ограничения, сравнение с литературой)
  • Выводы (что применимо на практике)
  • Ссылки (DOI/ссылки на открытый доступ)
  • Приложение (сырые данные, скрипты, дополнительные фото) — опционально

docs.title: Технические требования
docs.text:
• Формулы: KaTeX ($...$, $$...$$)
  • Изображения: images/ или ссылки; указывайте источники
  • Единицы: SI; четкие подписи
  • Повторяемость: параметры режимов, настройки оборудования, детали подготовки образцов

docs.title: Как отправить
docs.text:
1. Создайте ветку и добавьте файл в articles/ (пример: articles/2025-11-исследование-GMAW-импульс.md).
  2. Заполните разделы по шаблону.
  3. Откройте Pull Request и приложите превью (скриншоты/рендер локального сайта).
  4. При необходимости создайте Issue «Предложить статью» для обсуждения перед PR.

docs.title: 1. Source Type
docs.text:
• TIG welding power source (GTAW)
  • Inverter or transformer type
  • Direct current (DC)

docs.title: 2. Volt-Ampere Characteristic (V-A Curve)
docs.text:
CRITICALLY IMPORTANT: Power source must have sloped V-A curve

✅ Suitable characteristics: - Adjustable sloped V-A curve: 0.5-2.0 V/A - Optimal: 1.0-1.5 V/A - Higher coefficient = softer arc

❌ NOT suitable: - Constant current (flat) characteristic only - Sources without V-A curve adjustment - Characteristics with coefficient <0.5 V/A

How to check: - Study the power source user manual - Look for parameters: "slope", "droop", "V/A" - Some machines label this as "inductance"

docs.title: 3. High-Frequency Ignition (HF Start)
docs.text:
Mandatory feature: - Oscillator for contactless arc ignition - Operating mode: "Start Only" (pulses only during ignition) - Frequency: typically 150-500 kHz - Amplitude: 2000-6000 V

HF Modes: - ✅ "HF Start" or "Start Only" - pulses only at start - ⚠️ "Continuous HF" - constant pulses (may work but less reliable) - ❌ Without HF - method not applicable

docs.title: 4. Current Range
docs.text: For thin metal welding: - Minimum current: from 20-30 A - Maximum current: up to 80-100 A (sufficient) - Smooth current adjustment

docs.title: 5. Open Circuit Voltage
docs.text:
• Standard for TIG: 50-90 V
  • Sufficient for arc ignition through coating

docs.title: Additional Useful Features
docs.text:
Desirable to have: - Pre-flow time adjustment - Post-flow time adjustment - Down slope (current ramp-down) - Foot pedal or button for current control

Can work without: - Pulse mode - AC mode for aluminum - Hot start (compensated by HF)

docs.title: Recommended Electrodes
docs.text:
Type: LB52U or equivalent - Coating: basic (lime-type) - Application: low-alloy and high-strength steels - Standard: typically complies with AWS E7018 or equivalents

Electrode diameter based on metal thickness:

Metal Thickness Electrode Diameter Note 1.0 mm 2.0 mm Minimum diameter 1.5 mm 2.0-2.5 mm Optimal choice 2.0 mm 2.5 mm Standard 2.5+ mm 3.0 mm If necessary

⚠️ Important: Do not use electrodes larger than 3 mm for thin metal!

docs.title: Electrode Quality Requirements
docs.text:
1. Storage
  2. Dry location
  3. Temperature above dew point

  4. Original packaging until use

  5. Baking (if required)

  6. According to manufacturer's instructions
  7. Typically: 300-350°C, 1-2 hours

  8. Storage in electrode oven at 80-100°C

  9. Coating Condition

  10. No cracks or chips
  11. Uniform coating
  12. No moisture traces

docs.title: Step 1: Operating Mode Selection
docs.text:
1. Turn on the power source
  2. Select TIG (DC) mode
  3. Direct current
  4. GTAW mode
  5. Activate high-frequency ignition
  6. Set "HF Start" or "Start Only"
  7. DO NOT use "Lift TIG" or "Scratch Start"

docs.title: Step 2: V-A Curve Adjustment
docs.text:
Setting slope characteristic:

  1. Find the parameter:
  2. "Slope" (droop)
  3. "Inductance"

  4. "V/A" or similar

  5. Set value: 1.0-1.5 V/A

  6. Start with 1.2 V/A
  7. If arc is unstable - increase to 1.5 V/A
  8. If excessive spatter - reduce to 1.0 V/A

V-A Curve Selection Table:

V/A Coefficient Arc Character Application 0.5-0.8 Stiffer Experienced welders, thickness >1.5 mm 1.0-1.2 Balanced Universal choice 1.3-1.5 Soft Beginners, thickness <1.5 mm 1.6-2.0 Very soft Extra thin metal

docs.title: Step 3: Working Current Setting
docs.text:
Initial values:

Formula: I (A) ≈ 30 × d (mm)

where d = electrode diameter

Electrode Diameter Initial Current Adjustment Range 2.0 mm 50-60 A 40-70 A 2.5 mm 60-70 A 50-80 A 3.0 mm 70-80 A 60-90 A

Adjustment by metal thickness:

Metal Thickness Current Adjustment 1.0 mm -10...15 A from base 1.5 mm -5...10 A from base 2.0 mm Base value 2.5+ mm +5...10 A from base

docs.title: Step 4: Polarity Setting
docs.text:
For LB52U type electrodes: - ✅ Reverse polarity (DCEP) - Electrode holder on "+" (positive) - Ground on "-" (negative)

Check: Most TIG power sources have standard straight polarity (electrode negative). For coated electrode work reverse the polarity.

docs.title: Step 5: Additional Parameters
docs.text:
Pre-Flow (gas pre-flow): - Set minimum value or 0 sec - Gas shielding not used

Post-Flow (post-weld purge): - Set minimum value or 0 sec

Down Slope (current ramp-down): - Set minimum value or 0 sec - Not required for intermittent welding

docs.title: Equipment and Tools
docs.text:
Mandatory: 1. Welding power source (configured per above instructions) 2. Electrode holder for SMAW 3. Ground cable 4. LB52U electrodes of appropriate diameter 5. Personal protective equipment (see "Safety" section)

Recommended: 1. Metal samples for test welds 2. Wire brush for cleaning 3. Chipping hammer for slag removal 4. Sandpaper or file for electrode cleaning 5. Measuring tools (calipers, ruler)

docs.title: Part Preparation
docs.text:
1. Surface Cleaning
  2. Remove scale, rust, paint
  3. Clean 20-30 mm width from weld

  4. Degrease with acetone or solvent

  5. Assembly and Tack Welds

  6. Minimum gaps (0-0.5 mm)
  7. Tack welds every 20-30 mm

  8. Tack length: 5-10 mm

  9. Part Fixturing

  10. Use clamps or fixtures
  11. Ensure free access to weld area
  12. Provide for heat dissipation (backing strips)

docs.title: Ground Placement
docs.text:
Critical for arc stability!

✅ Correct placement: - As close as possible to weld area - Reliable electrical contact - Clean surface at attachment point

❌ Incorrect placement: - Far from weld area - Through intermediate parts - On painted or oxidized surface

Magnetic blow problem: - Can occur due to improper ground placement - Arc "blows" to one side - Solution: relocate ground to opposite side of weld

docs.title: Pre-Weld Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Power source configured per instructions
  • [ ] V-A curve set in 1.0-1.5 V/A range
  • [ ] High-frequency ignition activated
  • [ ] Reverse polarity (electrode on "+")
  • [ ] Current set per table
  • [ ] Ground securely attached close to weld area
  • [ ] Electrodes dry, undamaged
  • [ ] Protective equipment worn
  • [ ] Test samples prepared

docs.title: Test Ignition
docs.text:
1. Prepare metal sample
  2. Thickness matches working parts

  3. Clean surface

  4. First ignition

  5. Bring electrode to 3-5 mm distance
  6. Activate HF ignition (usually automatic when button pressed)

  7. Arc should ignite without contact

  8. Arc quality assessment

  9. Sound: smooth, hissing
  10. Color: bright white in center
  11. Stability: minimal fluctuations

  12. Spatter: minimal

  13. Re-ignition test

  14. Break the arc
  15. Let electrode cool 1-2 seconds
  16. Re-ignite through vitrified coating
  17. Should work without problems

docs.title: Signs of Proper Setup
docs.text:
✅ All good: - Arc ignites easily and quickly - Burns smoothly, without crackling - Re-ignition works through vitrified coating - Electrode doesn't stick - Minimal spatter

❌ Requires adjustment: - Arc crackles and "spits" → increase V-A curve slope - Frequent sticking → increase V-A curve slope or current - Won't re-ignite → check HF ignition - Excessive spatter → decrease current or V-A curve slope - Burn-through → decrease current

docs.title: For Different Metal Thicknesses
docs.text:
1.0 mm metal: - Current: 10-15 A below base - V-A curve: 1.3-1.5 V/A (softer) - Technique: short pulses with pauses

1.5 mm metal: - Current: 5-10 A below base - V-A curve: 1.2-1.4 V/A (standard) - Technique: medium duration pulses

2.0 mm metal: - Current: base value - V-A curve: 1.0-1.2 V/A (can be stiffer) - Technique: continuous welding possible

docs.title: For Different Joint Types
docs.text:
Butt joint: - Minimum gap - Current: base - Thorough tack welding

Corner joint: - Current: +5-10 A from base - Direction: upward preferred

T-joint: - Current: +10 A from base - Electrode angle: 45° to both parts

Lap joint: - Current: base or +5 A - Arc direction: predominantly on lower part

docs.title: Regular Checks
docs.text:
Before each shift: - Check cables for damage - Clean electrode holder - Verify ground connection reliability

Weekly: - Clean power source ventilation openings - Check all connection tightness - Check HF ignition operation

Monthly: - Check cable insulation with megger - Check current calibration (if possible)

docs.title: Malfunction Signs
docs.text: ⚠️ Contact specialist if: - HF ignition not working or unstable - Power source overheats - Smell of burning or smoke - Current not adjusting - Frequent protection trips

docs.title: Personal Protective Equipment
docs.text:
Mandatory: 1. Welding helmet with shade DIN 9-11 2. Welding gloves (gauntlets) 3. Protective clothing from non-flammable material 4. Closed-toe shoes with rubber soles

Recommended: 1. Respirator (basic-coated electrodes produce heavy fumes) 2. Safety glasses under helmet 3. Apron from non-flammable material

docs.title: Electrical Safety
docs.text:
⚠️ DANGER: - High-frequency pulses can be dangerous for people with pacemakers - Do not touch electrode and parts under voltage - Work in dielectric gloves when humid

Rules: - Power source grounding mandatory - Use serviceable cables - Do not work in rain or puddles - Insulate yourself from ground (rubber mat)

docs.title: Fire Safety
docs.text: Requirements: - Fire extinguisher within reach - Remove flammable materials 5 m away - Spark-arresting screens if necessary - Monitor sparks and metal spatter

docs.title: Ventilation
docs.text:
Mandatory: - Natural or forced ventilation - LB52U electrodes emit toxic fumes - Especially critical in confined spaces - Use exhaust or respirator

Next step: After equipment setup, proceed to Welding Parameters section to study specific operating modes.

docs.title: Technical Requirements
docs.text:
Format: - Preferred: JPEG for photos, PNG for diagrams - Resolution: minimum 1920x1080 pixels - Quality: high, without lossy compression

Lighting: - Good even lighting - Avoid glare and shadows - For welding arc: darken to see details

Composition: - Clear focus on important details - Minimal distracting elements - Use ruler or coin for scale

docs.title: 1. Equipment
docs.text:
• Power source with visible settings
  • Control panel with close-up of parameters
  • Electrode holder
  • Ground placement

docs.title: 2. V-A Curve Setup
docs.text:
• Screen or knobs with V/A value set
  • Example of "flat" and "sloped" characteristics
  • Power source settings menu

docs.title: 3. Electrodes
docs.text:
• New LB52U electrode
  • Vitrified tip after first ignition
  • Comparison of different diameters
  • Proper and improper tip sharpening (if applicable)

docs.title: 4. Welding Technique
docs.text:
• Arc length (use arrows or markings)
  • Electrode angle (with protractor or angle markings)
  • Welder's hand position
  • Intermittent technique (photo series)

docs.title: 5. Quality Welds
docs.text:
• Welds on 1, 1.5, 2 mm metal
  • Different joint types (butt, corner, T-joint)
  • Weld cross-section showing penetration
  • Macrostructure (after etching)

docs.title: 6. Defects
docs.text:
• Burn-through
  • Lack of penetration
  • Excessive spatter
  • Porosity
  • Cracks
  • Uneven bead

docs.title: 7. Diagrams and Charts
docs.text:
• V-A curve graph (flat vs sloped)
  • Equipment connection diagram
  • Pulse and pause timing diagram
  • Mode tables (in graphical form)

docs.title: Formatting Rules
docs.text:
Photo Captions: 

![Description](images/folder/file.jpg)
*Fig. X. Detailed description of what is shown*

Markings on Photos: - Use arrows to indicate important details - Add text labels (dimensions, parameters) - Use contrasting colors (red, yellow on dark background)

Scale: - Always include ruler or known object for scale - Specify actual dimensions in description

docs.title: Your Photos
docs.text: If adding your own photographs: - Ensure you have right to publish - Photos must comply with repository license (CC BY-SA 4.0) - Credit authorship in commit message

docs.title: Others' Images
docs.text: If using images from other sources: - Obtain author's permission - Credit source and author - Ensure license compatibility - DO NOT use images from commercial sites without permission

docs.title: Photo Description Template
docs.text:
When adding photos, create description file:

# Image Description

**File:** filename.jpg  
**Date:** DD.MM.YYYY  
**Author:** Your name or pseudonym  
**License:** CC BY-SA 4.0

## Shooting Parameters
- Camera/phone: _________
- Lighting: _________
- Processing: _________

## Description
Detailed description of what is shown in the photo.

## Welding Parameters (if applicable)
- Material: _________
- Thickness: _____ mm
- Electrode: LB52U _____ mm
- Current: _____ A
- V-A curve: _____ V/A
- Technique: _________

## Notes
Any additional comments, features, what to pay attention to.

docs.title: Equipment Photos
docs.text:
✅ Good: - Clear image of control panel - All settings and indicators visible - Good lighting - Parameter values indicated

❌ Bad: - Blurred image - Screen glare - Important details not visible - No context

docs.title: Weld Photos
docs.text:
✅ Good: - Weld cleaned of slag - Structure and shape visible - Ruler for scale included - Welding parameters specified

❌ Bad: - Weld covered in slag - Poor lighting - No scale - Unknown parameters

docs.title: How to Add Images
docs.text:
1. Create quality photos per recommendations
  2. Optimize size (no more than 2-3 MB per file)
  3. Name files meaningfully (e.g., weld-1mm-50A-good.jpg)
  4. Place in appropriate folder
  5. Add description in markdown documents
  6. Create Pull Request with description of added images

docs.title: Allowed Processing
docs.text:
✅ Allowed: - Cropping - Brightness/contrast correction - Adding arrows and labels - Scaling (reduction only) - Format conversion

❌ Not allowed: - Significant color alteration - Removing weld defects - Montage/composition from multiple photos without indication - Applying reality-distorting filters

docs.title: Recommended Tools
docs.text:
Free: - GIMP (multifunctional editor) - Paint.NET (simple editor for Windows) - Inkscape (for vector diagrams) - draw.io or diagrams.net (for diagrams)

Online: - Photopea (Photoshop analog) - Canva (for adding annotations)

docs.title: Contributing to Image Collection
docs.text:
We welcome contributions of quality photos and diagrams!

Especially needed: - [ ] Photos of various TIG power sources with V-A curve settings - [ ] Weld examples on different metal thicknesses - [ ] Weld macrostructure (cross-sections) - [ ] Various defects with cause indication - [ ] Equipment connection diagrams - [ ] Process diagrams (pulses, heat input) - [ ] HF ignition process photos (if possible to capture)

How to contribute: 1. Take quality photos 2. Prepare description 3. Create Pull Request 4. Wait for review and publication

docs.title: Contacts
docs.text:
For image questions: - Create Issue with "images" tag - Describe what photos are needed - Or suggest your photos

Thank you for contributing to the project!

Quality illustrations make documentation understandable and accessible to all skill levels.

docs.text: Electrode Diameter (mm) Current (A) Arc Voltage (V) Arc Length (mm) Welding Speed (mm/s) 2.0 40-70 18-24 1-2 3-5 2.5 50-80 20-26 1-2 3-5 3.0 60-90 22-28 2-3 4-6

docs.title: Table 2: Parameters by Metal Thickness
docs.text: Metal Thickness (mm) Electrode Diameter (mm) Recommended Current (A) Welding Technique 1.0 2.0 30-40 Intermittent, short pulses 1.2 2.0 35-45 Intermittent or continuous 1.5 2.0-2.5 40-50 Intermittent or continuous 1.8 2.5 45-55 Continuous, intermittent possible 2.0 2.5 50-60 Continuous 2.5+ 2.5-3.0 60-70 Continuous

docs.title: Table 3: Parameters for Different Joint Types
docs.text: Joint Type Thickness (mm) Gap (mm) Current (A) Notes Butt 1.0 0 30-40 Thorough tack welding Butt 1.5 0-0.3 45-50 No edge prep Butt 2.0 0-0.5 50-60 Edge bevel possible Corner 1.0+1.0 - 35-45 Upward direction Corner 1.5+1.5 - 45-55 Any direction Corner 2.0+2.0 - 55-65 Any direction T-joint 1.0+1.5 - 40-50 45° angle to both parts T-joint 1.5+2.0 - 50-60 More heat to thick part Lap 1.0+1.0 - 35-45 Arc on lower part Lap 1.5+1.5 - 45-55 Uniform penetration

docs.title: 1. Arc Length
docs.text:
CRITICALLY IMPORTANT: Maintain the shortest possible arc!

  • Optimal: 1-2 mm (for 2-2.5 mm electrodes)
  • Maximum: 3 mm (for 3 mm electrode)
  • Too short: sticking risk, but easier to avoid with HF ignition
  • Too long: unstable arc, excessive spatter, lack of penetration

Visual control: - Correct arc: bright spot, clear boundaries - Too long: blurred spot, crackling, sparks - Too short: electrode "bogs down" in puddle

docs.title: 2. Electrode Angle
docs.text:
Flat position: - Angle to surface: 60-70° - Tilt: backward from welding direction by 10-20° - Transverse motion: minimal or none (for thin metal)

Vertical position: - Upward: 70-80° angle to surface - Downward: not recommended for thin metal - Short arcs, pulses

Horizontal position: - Angle: 70-80° to vertical wall - Slightly downward to prevent sagging

Overhead position: - Avoid if possible - Angle: 80-90° to surface - Only short pulses - Minimum current

docs.title: 3. Welding Speed
docs.text:
General rule: - Thinner metal → faster welding - Watch the weld pool - Uniform speed = uniform bead

Signs of correct speed: - Pool moves evenly behind electrode - Constant bead width - No burn-through or lack of penetration

Too fast: - Narrow convex bead - Lack of penetration - Edge fusion failure

Too slow: - Wide flat bead - Burn-through risk - Metal overheating

docs.title: Intermittent Technique for Thin Metal
docs.text: This is the key technique for 1-1.5 mm thick metal!

docs.title: Operating Principle
docs.text:
1. Arc Ignition
  2. Bring electrode to 3-5 mm
  3. Activate HF ignition

  4. Immediately close to 1-2 mm

  5. Working Pulse

  6. Duration: 0.5-1.5 seconds
  7. Form small weld pool

  8. Advance 5-10 mm

  9. Arc Break

  10. Quickly pull electrode back 5-7 mm
  11. Arc extinguishes

  12. Metal begins cooling

  13. Pause

  14. Duration: 0.5-2 seconds
  15. Observe pool solidification

  16. Prepare for next pulse

  17. Re-ignition

  18. Bring electrode to solidified pool
  19. HF ignition penetrates vitrified coating
  20. Continue the weld

docs.title: Pulse Parameters
docs.text:
For 1.0 mm thickness: - Pulse duration: 0.5-1.0 sec - Pause: 1.0-1.5 sec - Travel: 3-5 mm per pulse

For 1.5 mm thickness: - Pulse duration: 1.0-1.5 sec - Pause: 0.5-1.0 sec - Travel: 5-8 mm per pulse

For 2.0 mm thickness: - Pulse duration: 1.5-2.0 sec - Pause: 0.3-0.5 sec (or continuous) - Travel: 8-12 mm per pulse

docs.title: Working Rhythm
docs.text:
Important: Develop a stable rhythm!

Example: "One-two (pulse) - pause - One-two (pulse) - pause"

Uniform rhythm ensures: - Equal heat input along entire weld - Predictable quality - No overheating

docs.title: Continuous Welding
docs.text:
For metal from 1.5 mm, continuous welding without breaks is possible.

Technique: 1. Ignite arc 2. Maintain stable short arc (1-2 mm) 3. Move uniformly along joint 4. Minimal or no transverse motion 5. Watch the weld pool

Advantages: - Higher productivity - Continuous bead - Less vitrified coating inclusion in weld

Disadvantages: - More heat input - Distortion risk - Requires higher skill level

docs.title: Tack Welds
docs.text:
Purpose: Fix parts before final welding

Parameters: - Current: 20-30% below working current - Tack length: 5-10 mm - Distance between tacks: 20-30 mm - Technique: single short pulses

Sequence: 1. Ignite arc 2. Short pulse 0.5-1 sec 3. Form small fusion point 4. Break arc 5. Move to next point

HF Ignition Features: - No need to break vitrified coating - Fast movement between points - High productivity

docs.title: Spot Welding
docs.text:
Purpose: Join parts at discrete points without continuous bead

Parameters: - Current: working or +10-15% - Duration: 1-2 seconds - Spot diameter: 4-8 mm - Distance between spots: per design requirements

Technique: 1. HF ignition 2. Pulse with penetration formation 3. Arc break 4. Move to next point

docs.title: Welding Closed Contours
docs.text:
Problem: Metal is cold at start of weld, overheated at end

Solution:

  1. Weld Start:
  2. Begin with current 10% above working

  3. First 10-15 mm - metal preheating

  4. Middle Section:

  5. Working current

  6. Stable mode

  7. Weld End (tie-in):

  8. 20-30 mm before start, reduce current by 10-20%
  9. Tie in weld with 5-10 mm overlap
  10. Gradually reduce current (if Down Slope function available)

docs.title: Welding Dissimilar Thicknesses
docs.text:
Example: 1.0 mm + 2.0 mm

Principle: More heat to thick part, less to thin

Technique: 1. Current: average between values for each thickness 2. Electrode angle: directed predominantly toward thick part (60-70° to it) 3. Arc: more often on thick part, periodic touches to thin 4. Speed: medium, control penetration of thin part

Example mode: - Thicknesses: 1.0 + 2.0 mm - Electrode: 2.5 mm - Current: 45-50 A (between 40 for 1mm and 50-60 for 2mm) - Technique: intermittent, arc 70% time on thick, 30% on thin

docs.title: Visual Control
docs.text:
Observe:

  1. Arc Color
  2. Bright white center → normal
  3. Red, dark → insufficient current or long arc

  4. Too bright, blinding → excessive current

  5. Arc Sound

  6. Smooth hiss → normal
  7. Crackling, clicks → unstable arc, check V-A curve and arc length

  8. Humming → possible magnetic blow, relocate ground

  9. Weld Pool

  10. Uniform, mobile → normal
  11. Too large, sagging → reduce current or increase speed

  12. Small, solidifying quickly → increase current or slow down

  13. Bead Formation

  14. Uniform ripples → normal
  15. Convex narrow bead → increase current or slow down
  16. Wide flat → reduce current or speed up
  17. Burn-through → reduce current, increase speed, use intermittent

docs.title: Heat Input Control
docs.text:
Signs of overheating: - Metal begins glowing around weld - Distortion, warping - Burn-through - Weld pool too fluid

Actions for overheating: 1. Reduce current by 5-10 A 2. Increase welding speed 3. Increase pauses between pulses 4. Allow part to cool 5. Use copper backing for heat dissipation

Signs of insufficient heating: - Lack of penetration - Edge fusion failure - Convex weld - Slag removes poorly

Actions: 1. Increase current by 5-10 A 2. Reduce welding speed 3. Shorten pauses between pulses 4. Improve edge preparation

docs.title: Problem and Solution Table (Quick Reference)
docs.text: Problem Possible Cause Solution Arc won't ignite HF not working Check settings, enable HF Start Sticking V-A curve too stiff Increase V/A coefficient to 1.5-2.0 Excessive spatter Arc too long Reduce arc length to 1-2 mm Lack of penetration Insufficient current Increase current by 10-15 A Burn-through Excessive current Reduce current, use intermittent Arc deflects Magnetic blow Relocate ground Uneven bead Unstable speed Develop uniform rhythm Slag removes poorly Low current or wet electrodes Increase current, use dry electrodes

docs.title: Adaptation to Conditions
docs.text:
When welding outdoors: - Wind protection mandatory (screens) - Wind cools metal → increase current by 10% - More spatter from wind → use protective screens

At low air temperature: - Metal colder → increase current by 10-15% - Increase pulse duration - Preheat weld areas

At high humidity: - Mandatory use of baked electrodes - Store in electrode oven - Increased porosity probability

docs.title: Recommended Recording Format
docs.text:
For each successful mode, record:

Date: ___________
Material: ___________ Thickness: _____ + _____ mm
Joint type: ___________
Welding position: ___________

Electrode: LB52U _____ mm
Current: _____ A
V-A curve: _____ V/A
Polarity: reverse

Technique: continuous / intermittent
Pulse: _____ sec
Pause: _____ sec

Result: ___________
Notes: ___________

docs.title: Example Completed Mode Card
docs.text:
Date: 11/18/2025
Material: St3 Thickness: 1.5 + 1.5 mm
Joint type: butt
Welding position: flat

Electrode: LB52U 2.5 mm
Current: 50 A
V-A curve: 1.2 V/A
Polarity: reverse

Result: excellent, no burn-through, 100% penetration

docs.title: Pre-Weld Checklist
docs.text:
Print and use until method is fully mastered:

  • [ ] Power source on, TIG DC mode
  • [ ] V-A curve set: _____ V/A (recommended 1.0-1.5)
  • [ ] HF Start activated
  • [ ] Polarity: reverse (electrode on "+")
  • [ ] Current set: _____ A (per table)
  • [ ] Electrodes: LB52U _____ mm, dry
  • [ ] Ground: secure, close to weld area
  • [ ] Parts: cleaned, assembled, tacked
  • [ ] PPE: helmet, gloves, clothing, respirator
  • [ ] Ventilation: provided
  • [ ] Test samples: prepared
  • [ ] Test weld completed: result _____

Следующий шаг: При возникновении проблем обратитесь к разделу Устранение неполадок.

docs.title: Q: Do I need to create all image folders immediately?
docs.text: A: No, you can create just the main images/ folder and README.md in it. Create subfolders later when photos are ready.

docs.title: Q: Can I change repository structure after creation?
docs.text: A: Yes, structure can be changed anytime. GitHub saves all change history.

docs.title: Q: What if I make a mistake in a file?
docs.text: A: Just edit the file again. GitHub stores all versions, you can roll back to previous ones.

docs.title: Q: Are English filenames mandatory?
docs.text: A: No, you can use Russian names, but English ones are more universal and avoid encoding issues.

docs.title: Q: How do I add a project collaborator?
docs.text: A: Settings → Collaborators → Add people. Enter colleague's username and send invitation.

docs.title: Q: Can I upload PDFs instead of Markdown?
docs.text: A: You can, but Markdown is preferable: - Displays directly on GitHub - Easier to edit - Better for versioning - More convenient for search

docs.title: Q: How do I protect repository from accidental changes?
docs.text: A: Settings → Branches → Add rule. Enable "Require pull request before merging".

# Welding with TIG Power Source and Coated Electrodes

This section contains complete documentation on unconventional method of using TIG (GTAW) power source with MMA/SMAW coated electrodes.

## Section Contents

1. [Theory](theory.md) - Physical fundamentals and method justification
2. [Equipment Setup](equipment-setup.md) - Detailed setup guide
3. [Welding Parameters](welding-parameters.md) - Mode tables and technique
4. [Troubleshooting](troubleshooting.md) - Common problem solutions
5. [Images](images/) - Photos and diagrams

## Quick Start

1. Ensure your power source has sloped V-A curve (1-2 V/A)
2. Activate high-frequency ignition (HF Start)
3. Set reverse polarity
4. Start with current per [tables](welding-parameters.md)
5. Practice on samples!

## Warning

Method is non-standard equipment use. Before using:
- Study theoretical section
- Conduct tests on samples
- Ensure results meet requirements

## Questions and Discussion

- [Create Issue](../../issues/new) - for questions and problems
- [Discussions](../../discussions) - for general discussions

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This document describes the theoretical foundations of using a TIG welding power source with coated electrodes (MMA/SMAW type) for welding thin-walled parts.

docs.title: Initial Challenge
docs.text:
When welding thin-walled steel parts (1-2 mm thickness) with coated electrodes, specific problems arise:

  1. Need for Precise Heat Input Control
  2. Risk of burn-through in thin metal
  3. Distortion from overheating

  4. Necessity of intermittent welding to control temperature

  5. Vitrified Coating Problem

  6. After first ignition, LB52U type electrode coating melts
  7. Glassy crust forms
  8. Re-ignition by standard method (contact) is difficult or impossible

  9. Critical for spot welding and tack welds

  10. Standard Equipment Limitations

  11. SMAW power sources lack contactless ignition
  12. Requires mechanical breaking of vitrified crust
  13. Loss of time and reduced work quality

docs.title: Conditions for Stable Arc Formation
docs.text:
To maintain a stable welding arc, the following are required:

  1. Arc Gap Ionization
  2. Air gap must become electrically conductive
  3. Achieved at 6000-7000°C temperature

  4. Maintained by thermal and impact ionization

  5. Sufficient Voltage

  6. Open circuit voltage: 50-90 V

  7. Arc working voltage: 16-40 V

  8. Appropriate Current

  9. Depends on electrode diameter and coating type

  10. For thin metal: 30-60 A

  11. Arc Stabilization

  12. Electrode coating contains ionizing elements
  13. Provides thermionic emission and easy ionization

docs.title: Coated Electrode Characteristics
docs.text:
LB52U Type Electrodes: - Basic (lime-type) coating - Designed for low-alloy and high-strength steels - High mechanical properties of the weld - Require direct current reverse polarity (DCEP) - Coating easily vitrifies when melted

Re-ignition Problem: - Vitrified crust acts as dielectric - Standard open circuit voltage (50-80 V) cannot penetrate the crust - Requires either mechanical breaking or higher voltage

docs.title: MMA (SMAW) Characteristics
docs.text:
Drooping V-A Curve - ideal for coated electrodes: - Voltage drops significantly with current increase - Droop coefficient: typically 2-4 V/A - Provides arc self-regulation - Current is limited by characteristic during short circuit - Additional features: Arc Force, Hot Start

Advantages: - Stable arc with arc length fluctuations - No electrode sticking - Easy re-ignition

docs.title: TIG Characteristics
docs.text:
Constant Current (Flat) V-A Curve - standard for TIG: - Current remains nearly constant regardless of arc length - Precise current control - Optimal for non-consumable electrode

Problems When Used with Coated Electrodes: - Slightest arc length change causes sharp voltage spikes - Frequent electrode sticking when approaching - Unstable arc burning - No boost during short circuits

Sloped V-A Curve (e.g., 1.2 V/A) - compromise solution: - Intermediate characteristic between constant current and drooping - With 10 A current increase, voltage drops by 12 V - Softer arc behavior - Acceptable for coated electrode work

docs.title: Operating Principle
docs.text: Oscillator generates high-frequency high-voltage pulses: - Frequency: 150-500 kHz - Amplitude: 2000-6000 V - Pulse duration: several microseconds

docs.title: Breakdown Mechanism
docs.text:
1. High Voltage Penetrates Dielectric
  2. Even through vitrified coating crust

  3. Creates ionized channel

  4. Main Arc Initiation

  5. Main current begins flowing through ionized channel

  6. Arc ignites without mechanical contact

  7. Arc Maintenance

  8. After ignition, normal arc characteristic operates
  9. HF pulses shut off (in "Start Only" mode)

docs.title: Advantages for Our Application
docs.text:
1. Contactless Ignition
  2. No need to touch vitrified electrode to workpiece
  3. Eliminates sticking

  4. No coating damage

  5. Dielectric Breakthrough

  6. HF pulses penetrate vitrified crust

  7. Enables multiple re-ignitions

  8. Intermittent Welding Capability

  9. Critical for thin metal
  10. Precise heat input control

docs.title: Why the Combination Works
docs.text:
Sloped V-A Curve (1.2 V/A) Provides: - Sufficient arc stability - Self-regulation with minor length changes - Acceptable short circuit behavior

High-Frequency Ignition Adds: - Contactless ignition capability - Breakthrough of vitrified coating - Quick re-ignition for intermittent welding

Result: - Stable arc despite non-ideal characteristic - Spot welding and tack weld capability - Controlled heat input to thin metal

docs.title: Theoretical Limitations
docs.text:
1. V-A Curve Still Non-Optimal
  2. 1.2 V/A characteristic is softer than constant current but stiffer than ideal drooping
  3. Requires highly skilled welder

  4. Narrower range of operating parameters

  5. Lack of Specialized Functions

  6. No Arc Force - short circuit boost
  7. No Hot Start - enhanced starting

  8. No Anti-Stick - sticking protection

  9. Sticking Risk on Contact

  10. If electrode accidentally touches workpiece
  11. Characteristic won't provide separation impulse

docs.title: Practical Limitations
docs.text:
1. Metal Thickness
  2. Optimal: 1-2 mm
  3. Method loses advantages with thickness >3 mm

  4. Very thin metal (<0.8 mm) requires special caution

  5. Electrode Type

  6. Method verified with LB52U (basic coating)

  7. Other coating types require experimental verification

  8. Operator Requirements

  9. SMAW experience necessary
  10. Ability to maintain stable short arc
  11. Quick response to process changes

docs.title: Optimal Conditions
docs.text:
✅ Recommended for: - Welding thin-walled steel structures (1-2 mm) - Tack welds on thin metal - Spot welding with heat input control - Situations requiring intermittent welding - Availability of TIG source with adjustable sloped V-A curve

❌ Not recommended for: - Heavy-walled structures (>3 mm) - Long continuous welds (standard SMAW is better) - Critical structures without preliminary testing - Work by unqualified personnel

docs.title: Conclusions
docs.text:
Using a TIG power source with sloped V-A curve and high-frequency ignition for coated electrode welding:

  1. Theoretically Justified - combination compensates for each method's shortcomings
  2. Practically Applicable - confirmed by experiments
  3. Has Limitations - requires experience and not suitable for all tasks
  4. Solves Specific Problem - thin-walled part welding with heat input control

The method is a compromise solution when specialized equipment is unavailable, but provides acceptable results with proper application.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
1. Technology of Electric Fusion Welding / ed. by B.E. Paton
  2. Power Sources for Welding / V.V. Sidorov
  3. Welder's Handbook / ed. by V.V. Stepanov
  4. GOST 9466-75 - Coated Metal Electrodes
  5. GOST 9467-75 - Electrodes for Arc Welding of Steels and Surfacing

Note: This document describes non-standard equipment usage. Before using the method, conduct testing on samples and verify results meet technical requirements.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: This section will help diagnose and resolve the most common problems when using a TIG power source with coated electrodes.

docs.title: 🔴 Critical Problems (welding impossible)
docs.text:
• Arc won't ignite
  • Constant electrode sticking
  • Power source not working or overheating

docs.title: 🟠 Serious Problems (low quality)
docs.text:
• Metal burn-through
  • Lack of penetration
  • Strong magnetic blow
  • Excessive spatter

docs.title: 🟡 Moderate Problems (adjustment required)
docs.text:
• Unstable arc
  • Uneven bead
  • Poor slag removal
  • Periodic sticking

docs.title: Problem 1: Arc won't ignite at all
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Nothing happens when bringing electrode close - No characteristic sound from HF oscillator - No spark or corona

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: HF ignition not activated
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - Check power source settings - Ensure "HF Start" or "Start Only" mode selected - Listen for high-frequency beep when pressing button

Solution: 1. Enter power source settings menu 2. Find "HF" or "Start Mode" parameter 3. Set "HF Start" or "Start Only" 4. Save settings 5. Try again

docs.title: Cause B: Oscillator malfunction
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - HF activated in settings but no sound - No discharge when bringing electrode 2-3 mm from workpiece

Solution: 1. Check fuses in oscillator circuit (see manual) 2. Check high-voltage wire connections 3. If unsuccessful - contact repair specialist

docs.title: Cause C: Insufficient open circuit voltage
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - HF working (beep audible) - But arc won't ignite even at small distance (1-2 mm)

Solution: 1. Measure open circuit voltage (should be 50-80 V) 2. If below 50 V - possible power source malfunction 3. Contact specialist

docs.title: Cause D: Poor ground contact
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - HF working - Arc momentarily ignites and extinguishes

Solution: 1. Check ground clamp security 2. Clean contact point to bare metal 3. Ensure no oxides or paint 4. Move ground closer to weld area 5. Check ground cable integrity

docs.title: Cause E: Too thick vitrified coating
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - First ignition works - Re-ignition doesn't work, even with HF

Solution: 1. Lightly tap electrode tip with hammer 2. Or clean with sandpaper 3. Or break off last 2-3 mm of electrode 4. In future, use shorter pauses between pulses

docs.title: Problem 2: Arc ignites but immediately extinguishes
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Arc flashes for a fraction of a second - Immediately extinguishes even when approaching electrode

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Current too low
docs.text: Solution: - Increase current by 10-20 A - Minimum current for 2 mm electrode: 40 A - Minimum current for 2.5 mm electrode: 50 A

docs.title: Cause B: V-A curve too stiff
docs.text: Solution: - Increase slope coefficient to 1.5-2.0 V/A - Softer characteristic will make it easier to maintain arc

docs.title: Cause C: Wet electrodes
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - Electrodes stored in damp location - Coating flakes off easily

Solution: - Use baked electrodes - Baking temperature for LB52U: 300-350°C, 1-2 hours - Store in electrode oven at 80-100°C

docs.title: Problem 3: Arc ignites but very unstable
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Arc "jumps", crackles - Lots of sparks and spatter - Uneven sound

See section "Arc Stability Problems" for solutions

docs.title: Problem 4: Constant sticking with slightest approach
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Electrode sticks to workpiece when approaching - Impossible to maintain short arc

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: V-A curve too stiff
docs.text:
This is the most likely cause!

Solution: 1. Increase V-A curve slope coefficient 2. Start with 1.5 V/A 3. Increase to 2.0 V/A if needed 4. Softer characteristic will prevent short circuits

docs.title: Cause B: Insufficient current
docs.text: Solution: - Increase current by 10-15 A - Higher current will make it easier to maintain arc

docs.title: Cause C: Arc too short
docs.text: Solution: - Increase arc length to 2-3 mm - Can reduce to 1-2 mm after mastering technique

docs.title: Problem 5: Periodic sticking
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Electrode sticks sometimes - More often when reducing arc length

Solution: - Maintain more stable arc length - Don't let electrode touch weld pool - Slightly increase V-A curve coefficient (by 0.2-0.3 V/A)

docs.title: What to do if electrode sticks:
docs.text:
1. DO NOT pull hard - can damage coating
  2. Quickly move electrode holder aside - sometimes electrode breaks free
  3. If that doesn't help:
  4. Quickly release holder
  5. Free electrode
  6. Turn off power source
  7. Unscrew electrode from workpiece
  8. Clean electrode tip before continuing work

docs.title: Problem 6: Arc unstable, crackles, "spits"
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Uneven sound (crackling instead of hissing) - Lots of sparks and spatter - Arc "jumps"

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Arc too long
docs.text: Solution: - Reduce arc length to 1-2 mm - Hold electrode closer to workpiece

docs.title: Cause B: V-A curve too stiff
docs.text: Solution: - Increase slope coefficient to 1.3-1.5 V/A

docs.title: Cause C: Magnetic blow
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - Arc deflects to one side - Deflection always in same direction

Solution: 1. Move ground to opposite side of weld 2. Or to other end of workpiece 3. Change electrode angle 4. Reduce arc length to minimum 5. Demagnetize workpiece if magnetized

docs.title: Cause D: Poor electrode quality
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - Coating with cracks or chips - Electrodes dampened - Coating flakes off

Solution: - Use quality dry electrodes - Bake electrodes before use - Store in dry location

docs.title: Cause E: Power source instability
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - Arc unstable even with all correct settings - Current "floats"

Solution: - Check supply network (voltage should be stable) - Check reliability of all connections - Possible power source malfunction - contact specialist

docs.title: Problem 7: Arc deflects to side (magnetic blow)
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Arc clearly deflects from vertical - Weld pool asymmetric - Spatter flies predominantly in one direction

Causes: - Magnetic field from welding current - Incorrect ground placement - Workpiece magnetized - Proximity of ferromagnetic masses

Solutions:

1. Ground relocation: - Move ground to opposite side - Or to opposite end of workpiece - Arc will deflect toward ground

2. Change welding direction: - Weld in opposite direction - Arc will deflect backward, which is less critical

3. Reduce arc length: - Short arc (1-2 mm) less susceptible to deflection

4. Change electrode angle: - Tilt electrode against arc deflection direction

5. Demagnetize workpiece: - Use special demagnetizing equipment - Or heat and cool workpiece (reduces residual magnetism)

6. Increase current: - More powerful arc less susceptible to deflection

docs.title: Problem 8: Metal burn-through
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Through-holes in metal - Weld pool collapse - Uncontrolled metal flow

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Excessive current
docs.text: Solution: 1. Reduce current by 10-20 A 2. For 1 mm metal start with 30-40 A 3. Don't exceed recommended values from tables

docs.title: Cause B: Welding too slow
docs.text: Solution: - Increase electrode travel speed - Don't linger in one spot

docs.title: Cause C: Long pulses without pauses
docs.text: Solution: - Use intermittent technique - Reduce pulse duration to 0.5-1 sec - Increase pauses to 1-1.5 sec - Let metal cool between pulses

docs.title: Cause D: Gap between parts too large
docs.text: Solution: - Minimize gap (0-0.3 mm for 1-1.5 mm thickness) - Make more frequent tack welds - Use backing for large gaps

docs.title: Cause E: Contamination on metal
docs.text: Solution: - Thoroughly clean weld areas - Remove paint, scale, oil - Degrease with acetone or solvent

docs.title: Problem 9: Lack of penetration
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Weak joint - Convex weld - Edge non-fusion - Weld easily breaks off

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Insufficient current
docs.text: Solution: - Increase current by 10-20 A - Check current matches electrode diameter

docs.title: Cause B: Welding too fast
docs.text: Solution: - Reduce travel speed - Increase pulse duration - Watch weld pool formation

docs.title: Cause C: Arc too long
docs.text: Solution: - Reduce arc length to 1-2 mm - Hold electrode closer to workpiece

docs.title: Cause D: Poor edge preparation
docs.text: Solution: - Clean edges to shine - Remove oxides, rust - Bevel edges at angle for thickness >2 mm

docs.title: Cause E: Gap too large
docs.text: Solution: - Reduce gap between parts - Use more frequent tack welds - Increase current for large gaps

docs.title: Problem 10: Excessive metal spatter
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Heavy spatter around weld - Metal loss - Part contamination

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Arc too long
docs.text: Solution: - Reduce arc length to 1-2 mm - This is the most common cause of spatter

docs.title: Cause B: Excessive current
docs.text: Solution: - Reduce current by 5-10 A - Find optimal value

docs.title: Cause C: V-A curve too stiff
docs.text: Solution: - Increase slope coefficient to 1.3-1.5 V/A

docs.title: Cause D: Wet electrodes
docs.text: Solution: - Use dry baked electrodes - Store in electrode oven

docs.title: Cause E: Metal contamination
docs.text: Solution: - Thoroughly clean and degrease surface - Especially critical for thin metal

docs.title: Problem 11: Poor slag removal
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Slag won't detach or detaches with difficulty - Slag inclusions remain in metal - Uneven weld surface under slag

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Insufficient current
docs.text: Solution: - Increase current by 10-15 A - At low current slag "bakes on" to metal

docs.title: Cause B: Wet electrodes
docs.text: Solution: - Bake electrodes per instructions - Store in dry location or electrode oven - Wet LB52U electrodes give very poor slag removal

docs.title: Cause C: Too rapid cooling
docs.text: Solution: - Let weld cool naturally - Don't force-cool with water or air - Slag detaches easier after complete cooling

docs.title: Cause D: Incorrect welding mode
docs.text: Solution: - Check all parameters: current, V-A curve, arc length - Slag is indicator of correct mode - Easily removing slag = correct mode

docs.title: Problem 12: Porosity in weld metal
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Visible holes on surface or weld fracture - Joint weakening

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Wet electrodes
docs.text: Solution: - Mandatory baking of LB52U electrodes - Storage in electrode oven - Don't use electrodes exposed >4 hours in humid environment

docs.title: Cause B: Metal contamination
docs.text: Solution: - Thorough cleaning - Special attention: oil, paint, rust - Degreasing mandatory

docs.title: Cause C: Arc too long
docs.text: Solution: - Reduce arc length - Air enters weld zone with long arc

docs.title: Cause D: High welding speed
docs.text: Solution: - Slow down travel - Gases must have time to escape from pool

docs.title: Problem 13: Weld cracks
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Visible cracks in or near weld - Appear immediately or after cooling

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Rigid part fixturing
docs.text: Solution: - Allow for thermal deformation - Don't clamp parts too rigidly - Welding sequence: from center to edges

docs.title: Cause B: Too rapid cooling
docs.text: Solution: - Natural cooling - Don't cool with water or compressed air - Cover thick parts to slow cooling

docs.title: Cause C: Material incompatibility
docs.text: Solution: - Ensure LB52U electrodes suitable for base metal - Check steel grade - Use preheat if necessary

docs.title: Cause D: High carbon content in metal
docs.text: Solution: - Preheat to 150-200°C - Slow cooling - May require different electrodes

docs.title: Problem 14: Power source overheats and shuts down
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Thermal protection trips - Power source shuts down after several minutes - Overheat indicator lit

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Exceeding duty cycle
docs.text:
Diagnosis: - Check power source duty cycle at current used - Example: 60% duty cycle at 100A means 6 minutes work, 4 minutes pause

Solution: - Follow work mode per duty cycle - Take breaks - If continuous work needed - use lower current - Or choose power source with higher duty cycle

docs.title: Cause B: Poor power source ventilation
docs.text: Solution: 1. Check that ventilation openings not blocked 2. Clean internal dust (compressed air, power off) 3. Ensure free space around power source (minimum 30 cm) 4. Don't work in sun or hot room

docs.title: Cause C: Cooling system malfunction
docs.text: Solution: - Check fan operation - Contact specialist if needed

docs.title: Problem 15: HF ignition works unstably
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Sometimes ignites, sometimes doesn't - Weak sparks - Quiet or absent oscillator sound

Possible causes and solutions:

docs.title: Cause A: Poor contact in HF circuit
docs.text: Solution: 1. Check high-voltage wire connections 2. Tighten screw connections 3. Check for oxides on contacts

docs.title: Cause B: Oscillator capacitor wear
docs.text: Solution: - Contact specialist for capacitor replacement

docs.title: Cause C: Weak high-voltage pulses
docs.text: Solution: - Possible oscillator transformer malfunction - Requires qualified repair

docs.title: Problem 16: Current doesn't match setting
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Actual current differs from panel reading - Welding result doesn't match expected

Solution: 1. Check power source calibration (see manual) 2. Measure actual current with clamp meter 3. Perform calibration or contact specialist if needed 4. Temporary solution: adjust current setting by result

docs.title: Problem 17: Uneven weld
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Weld alternately wider and narrower - Varying bead height - Unstable quality

Solution: - Develop even work rhythm - Maintain stable travel speed - Use metronome or count to yourself - Practice on samples

docs.title: Problem 18: Can't do intermittent technique
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Arc goes out and won't reignite - Pauses too long - Lose short arc skill on reignition

Solution:

Exercise 1: Rhythm practice 1. Strike arc on sample 2. Count: "One-two" (1 sec pulse) 3. Break arc 4. "Pause" (0.5 sec pause) 5. Repeat 20-30 times in row

Exercise 2: Fixed distances 1. Mark line on sample with points every 5 mm 2. One pulse - one point 3. Achieve uniformity

Exercise 3: Reducing pauses 1. Start with 2 sec pauses 2. Gradually reduce to 0.5-1 sec 3. Learn to quickly find correct electrode position

docs.title: Problem 19: Can't maintain short arc
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Arc alternately too long or sticking - Unstable distance - Lots of spatter or sticking

Solution:

Exercise: Stability training 1. Strike arc 2. Hold electrode motionless 5-10 seconds 3. Watch weld pool 4. Develop muscle memory 5. Use hand rest (table edge, part)

Tip: - Hold electrode holder like pen - Fix wrist - Use small finger movements, not whole arm

docs.title: Quick problem diagnosis:
docs.text:
ARC WON'T IGNITE?
├─ HF not working → Check settings, enable HF Start
├─ HF works but arc won't ignite → Check ground, increase current
└─ Ignites and immediately goes out → Increase current, soften V-A to 1.5-2.0 V/A

CONSTANT STICKING?
├─ Stiff V-A → Increase to 1.5-2.0 V/A
├─ Low current → Increase by 10-15 A
└─ Arc too short → Increase length to 2-3 mm

UNSTABLE ARC?
├─ Long arc → Reduce to 1-2 mm
├─ Stiff V-A → Soften to 1.3-1.5 V/A
├─ Magnetic blow → Relocate ground
└─ Wet electrodes → Bake electrodes

BURN-THROUGH?
├─ High current → Reduce by 10-20 A
├─ Slow welding → Increase speed
└─ No pauses → Use intermittent technique

LACK OF PENETRATION?
├─ Low current → Increase by 10-20 A
├─ Fast welding → Reduce speed
└─ Long arc → Reduce to 1-2 mm

EXCESSIVE SPATTER?
├─ Long arc → Reduce to 1-2 mm (MOST COMMON CAUSE)
├─ High current → Reduce by 5-10 A
└─ Stiff V-A → Soften to 1.3-1.5 V/A

docs.title: Signs of serious equipment malfunction:
docs.text:
🚨 Immediately stop work and contact specialist:

  • Burning smell or smoke from power source
  • Sparking inside housing
  • Electric shock when touching housing
  • HF oscillator completely non-functional after all checks
  • Power source won't turn on
  • Constant protection trips even at low currents
  • Unusual sounds (humming, crackling) from power source
  • Visible board or component damage

docs.title: Preventive maintenance:
docs.text:
Annual service by specialist recommended: - Dust cleaning - Contact inspection - Capacitor check - Parameter calibration - Insulation check - Worn component replacement

Next step: If problems arise, refer to the Equipment Setup section for proper configuration or consult this troubleshooting guide.

docs.title: Статьи и опыт
docs.text:
В этом разделе — оригинальные исследования, практические методики, обзоры и кейсы. Хотите поделиться опытом? См. «Шаблоны материалов» и «Как внести вклад».

  • Пример статьи: Образец оформления

docs.title: Образец оформления статьи
docs.text:
Аннотация: кратко опишите цель, метод и основные результаты.

Ключевые слова: GMAW, перенос металла, импульсный режим, микроструктура

docs.title: Введение
docs.text: Краткий обзор области, постановка задачи, что вы проверяете.

docs.title: Методика
docs.text:
• Оборудование: источник тока, подающий механизм, горелка
  • Материалы: проволока, защитный газ, заготовки
  • Параметры: ток, напряжение, скорость подачи, дебит, зазор, угол горелки
  • Дизайн эксперимента: серии/повторности, контрольные точки

docs.title: Результаты
docs.text: Вставьте графики/таблицы/фото. Подпишите оси и единицы.

docs.title: Обсуждение
docs.text: Интерпретация наблюдений, сравнение с литературой, ограничения.

docs.title: Выводы
docs.text: Основные практические выводы и дальнейшие шаги.
